It is all the more appalling that, having flagged three weeks ago at a meeting of all the Whips that we regarded it as fundamental to the debate, not only in the interests of politicians but of the people outside, three-quarters of whom do not believe the publicity generated by the Taoiseach to date concerning the report of the tribunal, that there should be a question and answer session here dealing with the political ramifications as distinct from the personal or moral judgment of any individual assigned to ministerial office and that no such session is allowed. It is appalling that in a true and open democracy the Government has refused to answer to its peers on the legitimate claims and questions which should be answered in a political sense in this Chamber.

MainHeading.P: On 30 August 1994 I received a reply from the Government Chief Whip formally refusing our request for a question and answer session. He said:

As is normal practice in motions being debated in the Dáil, the Minister responding at the end of the debate will reply to any questions raised and so there will not be a specific question and answer session.

This is indicative of the debate so far. The Taoiseach in the course of his contribution said “There are no questions still to be answered”. A sixth class child observing this charade would understand there are hundreds of questions that need to be answered politically, not for the sake of the Government but for the democratic system that we the elected Members represent and for the electorate to whom we must answer. It is nauseating that Ministers and the Government as a unit with collective responsibility would refuse to answer questions arising from the political ramifications of what occurred a number of years ago.

The Taoiseach, we were told, looked forward with enthusiasm to this debate and the Tánaiste for years has expounded on the necessity of accountability in public life. Yet we have a situation where one complements the other. The Taoiseach did not mention the Labour Party in his contribution. The Tánaiste criticised but in a nice way and said that the Government did bad things previously but that he would continue on the same road. Let me remind Members of what Deputy Spring said on 17 October 1991, column 845 of the Official Report:
We have had secret agreements with beef barons as well as a number of much publicised deals.
This is the same deputy leader of Government who promised trust in politics and openness for the people.

Speaker.P: He repeated that yesterday.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Kenny Mr. E. Kenny
Speaker.P: I wonder will the answers be given by the Minister who winds up the debate or does that Minister really understand the flavour and complexity of the beef tribunal report presented by Judge Hamilton, including the vague references in it? I note the Taoiseach quoted the late US President, Lyndon Johnson, a man whose operations in the White House were doubtful on a number of issues.
There ought not to be references of that kind to the late President.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Kenny Mr. E. Kenny
Speaker.P: I am not sure he can come back to me at this stage.
That is not the point.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Kenny Mr. E. Kenny
Speaker.P: I was going to contrast his presidency with the great President Lincoln who said “democracy is of the people, by the people, for the people” but this charade is not either for, of or by the people.
Not in this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Kenny Mr. E. Kenny
Speaker.P: In response to a question from the then Deputy Keating the Taoiseach said on 7 April 1987 “I will answer any question from the Comptroller and Auditor General's Office”. This Government has failed to bring into this House the legislation to deal with compulsory attendance of witnesses at committees.
The Minister responsible for that area is present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Kenny Mr. E. Kenny
Speaker.P: If the Committee of Public Accounts, which has the backing of the Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General, puts down a series of questions I wonder if the Taoiseach, who looked forward with enthusiasm to the debate and who alleges he has been entirely vindicated, will go before that committee and answer legitimate questions of a political nature. When commenting on public accountability, Deputy Spring said on 17 October 1991, column 850 of the Official Report:

I want to make it very clear to the Taoiseach that I have no apology to make to him, his Government or anyone else in this House for my attendance at the tribunal and for my interest in ensuring that this Oireachtas is represented. In fact, given the patent nonsense which is being uttered by Minister after Minister throughout this debate, the tribunal may be a far more meaningful forum than the Dáil over the next few months.
I wonder about the change of mentality in people who put their necks on the line in the interest of democratic rights but who changed their tune so completely after achieving high office.
Deputy Spring, continuing, said:

When the Tribunal of Inquiry into the Beef Industry begins its detailed work, it will have to examine two key questions. The first of those questions involves the issue of whether or not there has been wrongdoing within the industry itself, under a number of headings — headings like fraud and tax evasion, to name just two. The second, and equally important issue concerns the relationship between the beef industry and politics. The questions raised by these issues must be answered because they go to the very heart of parliamentary democracy ...
He concludes, column 851 of the same volume:

MainHeading.P: Maybe after all this, the politicians who are now praising themselves for their vigilance and the need for vigilance will finally have self respect and decency to come into this House and apologise to people, ... and others, that they maligned in this House when they rightly raised matters of criminal activity in the beef sector.

It is the Labour Party that keeps this Government in office and it is the Labour Party that can remove it from office. It is the party who must judge whether the criteria laid down by the Tánaiste prior to entering Government are still satisfied.

Regretfully, Sir, I have to give notice that there is no method of sanction in this House other than the Committee on Procedure and Privileges, which you chair honourably, that can censure any Deputy for stepping beyond his or her remit in making allegations, claims of statements in this House. A number of months ago a Fine Gael Deputy, Deputy Jim Mitchell, made certain allegations in this House for which the Taoiseach threatened him with removal from the chairmanship of the Committee of Public Accounts. You, Sir, are aware of the lengths and extremes to which we went to ensure that verbally at least Deputy Mitchell put forward a statement which was compatible with his remit and moral duty as a representative of this House.

What happens to people who have committed the ultimate political sacrilege, who have walked into this Chamber, having been given the seal of office and a remit by the President, and who knowingly have been sparing with the truth, who knowingly have been inaccurate or economical with the accuracy of the information they gave to the House?

Speaker.P: The Deputy may not attribute falsehood in that manner to any Member of this House.
It could be his own he is talking about.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Kenny Mr. E. Kenny
Speaker.P: It could be——
It is a long-standing rule.
We have never been ashamed to do something about discipline——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Kenny Mr. E. Kenny
Speaker.P: I will deal with Deputy Power. If we had a proper political forum here there would be an obligation upon those in the Opposition, who have made allegations which cannot stand up, to withdraw them also. One does not need to be Colombo or Sherlock Holmes to deduce from the statements made here over the past three days that certain people with red files in their hands did not give a full and overall answer to questions they were asked. I hope at least to investigate the possibility of dealing with this through the Committee on Procedure and Privileges. That is the only committee which can in any way censure Deputies who have stepped out of line in terms of their remit as public representatives.

I find it nauseating that this Government, with a majority unprecedented in the history of the State, did not have the guts to answer political questions in a peer to peer relationship with their fellow elected representatives. This is a slur which will not go away from this Government. It will spread like a cancer upon the Ministers of Government and will be the main catalyst in their ultimate downfall.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. Foxe Mr. T. Foxe
Speaker.P: I wish to thank Deputy Enda Kenny and the Fine Gael Party for affording me time to contribute to the debate on this report.

MainHeading.P: I welcome the report. It should be good; it cost £36 million. The beef tribunal was set up originally to investigate allegations of illegalities made against factory owners, staff members of those factories, the Revenue Commissioners, certain politicians and various Departments. The allegations referred mainly to abuse of practices under which money was provided by the EU to meat processors. My fear at that time was that highlighting such malpractices would inflict untold damage on our beef trade. Fortunately, my thinking was incorrect because that has not come about and it is most unlikely to do so.

The beef industry is our greatest industry. That industry, in addition to live cattle exports, accounts for £1 billion of exports annually. In 1973, shortly after we joined the EC, the responsibility for operating the intervention system fell to the Minister for Agriculture. His functions were to purchase beef directly and indirectly, to pay grants such as APS, aids to private storage, and export refunds to farmers. In the 19-year period from 1973 to 1992, Ministers for Agriculture spent £8.5 billion on such purchases and aids.

Approximately 12 months ago there was much talk in this House concerning the £8 billion that we were to receive from Europe. That figure was reduced to £7.1 billion, then £6.4 billion and I am not sure what the figure is currently. Bearing in mind the outrage that was expressed at the prospect of not receiving the full £8 billion originally promised, one can get some idea of what the beef industry has contributed to this country during that 19 year period.

Of the £8.5 billion paid out by the Minister for Agriculture and his staff, a mere .04 per cent was found to be disallowed by the EU. That is a record any Department could be proud of either in this country or in any member country of the EU. The Department had at its disposal then, and continues to have, approximately 80 staff members for administration, 60 veterinarians and 234 agricultural officers. Their functions were to inspect the meat in the factories of which there were 50, and in the cold stores, of which there were 20, in addition to inspections on the deboning line.

Those inspections were originally carried out by staff who were permanently placed in the meat plants during working hours but as time went on it was discovered that that was not the most effective system. The interpretation of the myriad of EC regulations caused quite a problem. Almost on a daily basis there were requests for clarification of certain regulations. In October 1990, therefore, an inquiry team was established which proposed another system for carrying out inspections incorporating some of the old system and introducing ad hoc unannounced meat inspections in factories or deboning halls. This system was found to work extremely well, so much so that other EC member states complimented Ireland on its system of inspections and felt it should be copied as a model by other EC countries.

The primary responsibility for implementing those regulations rests with the operators, the factories and the meat plants but it rests also with the Department of Agriculture which must ensure that such compliance is effected. In recent years there has been a massive increase in the amount of work to be carried out by the Department inspectors. Between 1989 and 1990, the amount of beef going into intervention increased from 77,000 to 230,000 tonnes. Similarly, in the deboning halls, the amount of beef deboned increased from 59,000 tonnes in 1989 to 214,000 in 1990. That represented a massive increase in the workload and if any criticism can be made of the Department of Agriculture, it is that it was short staffed for far too long a period.

In recent times the live cattle trade attracted much criticism, not without due reason. However, the criticism had a certain validity. As a result the Department in conjunction with the factories thought it wise to diversify. Rather than export carcase beef it was decided to process more beef at home which would generate jobs and money.

In the eight year period which ended in 1992 the amount of beef exported in vacuum packs increased from 25,500 tonnes to 113,000 tonnes, a five-fold increase. I had feared an adverse reaction resulting from setting up the tribunal but those figures indicate there was no backlash. Our beef is of prime quality. If any shadow of doubt hung over the beef trade exports would not have increased on such a scale. A minimal number of complaints was received from other countries.

Over the last 12 months there was a change in the Common Agricultural Policy. In the past the trend was to purchase beef for intervention. Over the next four years the amount of beef going into intervention will be reduced by more than 50 per cent. In 1993, 750,000 tonnes of beef were sold into intervention but in 1997 that figure will be reduced to 350,000 tonnes. There will be an extra half a million tonnes of beef for which markets will have to be found. As there will be less reliance on intervention there will be fewer opportunities for fraud. Upgrading the inspection system is on going and in future there will be better communications between the gardaí, departmental officers and customs officials.

As regards the tribunal, some of the allegations of fraud made against factory owners were upheld as were allegations of fraud against staff members in those factories. Allegations of malpractice against the Revenue Commissioners were refuted as were allegations of malpractice against politicians. Allegations of an over-close relationship between politicians and certain people involved in fraud were refuted, although it was recognised that where a relationship existed it was not an unduly close one.

The tribunal criticised the Department of Agriculture for its inadequate number of staff. That can easily be rectified by the Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry recruiting staff in the near future. The chairman of the tribunal made some unpalatable remarks about this House. He said that if questions asked here had been answered in a more forthright and thorough manner there would have been no need for the tribunal.
The allegations of tax and intervention frauds upheld by the tribunal should be pursued and investigated and the full rigours of the law brought to bear on those found guilty.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The report of the beef tribunal chaired by Mr. Justice Liam Hamilton has examined in detail the actions of all those connected with the export credit scheme 1987-89, and the background to those actions, as well as investigating the operations of beef factories and other allied activities. It is thorough and painstaking documentation and analysis of a complex web of activities and it deals in detail with all the allegations made at the time, some founded on the rock of truth and others on the hot air of privileged speculation.

The report includes many recommendations which seek to remedy the obvious failings of systems and procedures as well as patent abuses of regulations and of the taxation system. It is of the utmost importance that these recommendations be implemented in accordance with Mr. Justice Hamilton's advice and that is the Government's intention, as outlined in the Programme for a Partnership Government.

MainHeading.P: As well as dealing with factual abuses that came to light at the time, great efforts were made to enmesh the Haughey Government of that period in claims of “golden circles”, “favouritism” and “back-room deals”. During the inquiry into these matters certain politicians sought to impugn the integrity and motivation of the Taoiseach and, as if the matters dealt with by Mr. Justice Hamilton were not enough material for this important debate, there are those who continue to create further scenarios and subplots in a drama that already had more than its quota of both. It is clear to any fair-minded person and it is stated clearly by Mr. Justice Hamilton that the Minister for Industry and Commerce at the time, now Taoiseach, Deputy Albert Reynolds, acted in the national interest at all times and those who watched his actions as Minister for Industry and Commerce, Minister for Finance and latterly as Taoiseach, know full well that his motivation is of the highest calibre. The fact that succeeding Cabinets have also worked to the same the high standard may not make Deputy Reynolds exceptional but there can be no question about his motives, motivation and conduct. They were, and continue to be, of the same high standard.

While there may have been a breakdown in policy co-ordination along the way, the aims and objectives of the then Minister and his Government were always to build up a viable food industry, to stimulate and strengthen the agricultural sector, to increase our exports and provide downstream employment. With the benefit of hindsight, the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and all the consequential events. post hoc arguments have been advanced to impute incompetence and ministerial action in direct contravention of departmental advice. Much has been made of this.

Civil servants provide back-up information and advice for Ministers but, at the end of the day it is the Minister who must make the decision, and stand up and justify that decision. That is the Minister's job.

Speaker.P: Answer the questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: This is merely fulfilling the task for which we were elected to Dáil Éireann, and exercising the trust that bestowed on us by the Taoiseach of the day. Our decisions are informed by our own experience, by briefing from within and without the Department, from Cabinet discussions and information that comes to us from delegations, submissions and representations. In my Department I have often been castigated for listening too much to my officials; the Taoiseach has been castigated for the opposite. The files in the Department of Finance tell many tales of Ministers who took departmental advice and Ministers who disregarded it. I will not tell tales out of school and cite cases where acceptance of advice would certainly have been the better option. As Minister you give it your best shot, and by that you stand or fall. However, I want to instance one case when a Minister for Finance went against all the advice offered him. It refers to the occasion when it was necessary to put a value on the Greencore shares for flotation in April 1991. All the advice given to the Minister was to value the shares at between £2,20 and £2.30. In spite of much pressure to opt for that range the Minister held out right to the very end and finally got agreement at £2.35 per share. That Minister is now Taoiseach.

I was a member of the Government at the time of the Goodman plan and I can assure the House that all our efforts were directed towards developing a value-added quality beef industry which would deliver a much bigger segment of the continental market for Irish-produced beef and consequent increased employment at home. There was never any question of favouring any particular individual or company. Rather the entire emphasis was to deliver an increased market share in the shortest possible time.

MainHeading.P: Before going on to deal, in detail, with the major issues connected with my brief, I want to refer to two other issues that concern me. I would like to deal first with the cost of the tribunal. The House will already be aware that I have expressed concern at the rates applicable to attendance by counsel at hearings. It seems extraordinary that in this age of deregulation and competition there is what seems like a virtual cartel system applying to legal fees. My Department has already issued instructions to all Departments in this regard and will continuously review the matter with a view to minimising such costs. I will return later to the question of the overall cost of the tribunal.

The second issue that concerns me is the question of the assignment of costs. I know that the chairman of the tribunal has under law the power to assign the costs of the tribunal to the State. However, I have some difficulty in accepting that the costs of companies which have been found by the tribunal to have practised large scale tax evasion should be borne by the State. I find this most difficult to accept. In these circumstances I will be vigorously contesting the extent of the cost and will be seeking substantial reductions on the grounds that, in certain instances at least, the extent of the legal representation was unwarranted.

I now want to deal with those aspects of the beef tribunal report which refer directly to my Department and to the role and functions of the Revenue Commissioners with regard to customs and tax enforcement. The report makes one specific recommendation in relation to the duties of auditors to report tax evasion to the proper authorities. I will deal later with that recommendation. I would like to say at the outset that I welcome the findings of the tribunal in these areas.

In its various findings the tribunal has upheld the independence and integrity of the Revenue Commissioners, rejected the allegations made against the Customs Service and endorsed the tax settlement reached with the Goodman Group in 1991 in relation to tax avoidance schemes. The tribunal found that tax evasion took place on a substantial scale. This is a matter of great concern to me and the Government, as all tax evasion is, but it accepted that the nature of the tax evasion scheme made it difficult to detect in the ordinary course at the time. It found that no special favours were done by my Department in the Finance Acts to prefer one particular firm.

I would like to deal with the very serious allegations which called into question the long-respected and valued independence, integrity and capacity of the Revenue Commissioners and their officials. These allegations were made in the ITV “World in Action” programme and in both Houses of the Oireachtas and suggested that the Revenue Commissioners and their officials had turned a blind eye to Customs fraud and tax evasion, had made wrong judgments in settlements with certain companies and were the subject of political influences.

In the first instance I want to emphasise that the Revenue Commissioners and their staff provided the fullest assistance and support to the tribunal in investigating the allegations made. The report of the tribunal acknowledges the assistance and support provided and singles out some of the officials concerned for special mention. The report concludes that all the relevant allegations were without foundation.

As regards Customs operations, the tribunal, in rejecting all the allegations made, found that the operations were detailed and thorough and that suggestions that they were subject to outside influence from any source are completely without foundation. The report indicates that there was no basis for allegations that the Revenue Commissioners had turned a “blind eye” to the activities of the Goodman Group in relation to tax evasion. It further states “unreservedly” that the tribunal is satisfied that the Revenue Commissioners did not make a wrong judgment in agreeing to a settlement on certain income tax and corporation tax avoidance matters with the Goodman Group in 1991 and concludes that the settlement reached was a fair and reasonable one.

Since the foundation of the State, and for reasons that have stood the test of time, the Oireachtas has taken responsibility for the administration of customs and tax law out of political control and vested it in the hands of appointed commissioners. The independence of the Commissioners in relation to individual cases is a vital principle which has helped to foster the confidence of the public in the administration of the tax system. It is against that background that I welcome the findings of the tribunal in rejecting these particular allegations. Given the gravity of the allegations some more detailed comment is warranted. I will first deal with Customs matters and then move on to comment on the questions of tax evasion and avoidance.

The Customs service plays an important role in controlling and checking exports of CAP goods entitled to export refunds. The Customs control system is designed to constitute an effective check on the accuracy of declarations made by traders and to deter and detect irregularities. Irregularities discovered are reported to the Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry which is the paying agency for CAP purposes.

A number of allegations about Customs were examined by the tribunal. These concerned customs' inspections on the Border and at Greenore port, an alleged carousel operation and alleged collusion between AIBP and Customs — the so-called “master plan”— to frustrate an investigation at Waterford-Ballymun plants.

In relation to inspections on the Border and at Greenore, the report of the tribunal states that there was no basis whatsoever for the suggestion that the Goodman companies were subjected to a lesser degree of Customs inspections than other commercial operations — page 366.

The tribunal also accepted that the incident portrayed as being a “carousel operation”— whereby meat is exported on which export refund is paid, secretly reimported and then re-exported to claim yet more export refunds — was not part of a carousel scam. Contrary to the allegation that no action was taken in respect of the incident, the tribunal acknowledged that a very thorough investigation was carried out by Customs which established the facts of the case — page 375. The tribunal was satisfied that this investigation was not in any way hindered by any person in authority, political or otherwise, and was a completely independent investigation. I should add that in this case a deposit of £10,000, which was required by Customs prior to release of the truck involved, was retained by Customs.

In the case of Waterford-Ballymun, the tribunal rejected the allegation of collusion between AIBP and Customs to frustrate the investigation as completely and utterly without foundation — page 404 — and concluded that the Waterford-Ballymun investigation carried out by the Customs and Excise authorities, with the assistance of the Department of Agriculture officials concerned, was detailed and exhaustive.

Much was made of the delay in the Gards Fraud Squad obtaining a copy of the Customs and Excise report of this investigation. Some delay arose because a written request from the Garda authorities for its release went astray and was not received by the Customs authorities. The report was given to the Garda authorities after a copy of the original letter requesting its release was given to Customs. The tribunal report found nothing sinister in this delay. I should add that new arrangements were introduced in 1991 to ensure that the Garda Fraud Squad is alerted at an early stage to any fraud possibility arising from Customs investigations. Contacts are established directly between Customs and Garda so as to ensure that there is no unnecessary delay in commencing criminal investigations.

While the operation and control of the aids to private storage, APS, scheme is a matter for the Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry, beef placed under this scheme may also be placed under Customs control for export refund purposes. The 1988 APS scheme was subjected to a joint investigation conducted by Customs and Excise and the Department of Agriculture.

Having examined all the evidence presented, the tribunal was satisfied that the joint sampling operation carried out was detailed, thorough and exhaustive. On the basis of the findings, penalties in excess of £3.6 million were imposed by the Department of Agriculture on the companies that were found to have breached the regulations — page 437.

I would also like to draw the attention of the House to Table II set out in pages 586-591 of the tribunal report. This table outlines the more serious irregularities uncovered in the beef sector between 1980 and 1991. Apart from the Customs investigations I have already dealt with, this table shows a further 18 irregularities involving 17 companies where Customs personnel were involved in the detection or investigation of the irregularities. The amounts involved amounted to in excess of £4 million.

The findings of the tribunal confirm that the Customs controls have been operating well. Nevertheless, the Revenue Commissioners have informed me that they are fully alive to the need to keep the effectiveness of the controls under review and to introduce changes were found necessary.

Following a management review of the overall organisation of Revenue after completion of the Single Market, a number of new measures were introduced early this year to further improve the management and control of Revenue's operations in the export refund regime: first, a more streamlined management and reporting system has been introduced whereby overall responsibility for the proper implementation of CAP rules on export refunds has been assigned to one assistant secretary in Revenue; second, a systems audit function has been set up in head office to provide a greater focus on the integrity of control arrangements. Staff assigned to this work carry out ongoing critical review of CAP control systems to verify, as far as possible, whether controls in place are fully effective, to identify weaknesses, and to make improvements where appropriate; third, staff in head office have also been assigned responsibility for carrying out regular inspection visits to customs stations throughout the country to confirm that the control system is being implemented properly by the control staff. This complements local supervision and fourth. Revenue is represented on the new committee established by the Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry to oversee the audit programmes for CAP operations.

These measures demonstrate a strong commitment by Revenue to provide and maintain an effective Customs control system for beef eligible for export refund and to detect and pursue irregularities in co-operation with the Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry.

A number of allegations were made about the £4.5 million settlement on tax avoidance matters which was concluded by Revenue with the Goodman Group, during the period of its examinership in 1990-91. The allegations suggested that the Revenue wrote off tax on under-the-counter payments, gave a special £4 million concession, and agreed not to take proceedings in respect of large scale tax evasion.

I am glad to note the tribunal “unreservedly” rejected the allegations made and found that the Revenue Commissioners did not make a wrong judgment, that there was a real issue as to the extent of the Goodman group's liability in respect of income tax and corporation profits tax and that the settlement reached was a fair and reasonable one having regard to the circumstances.

The 1991 settlement related to tax avoidance schemes — dividend companies etc. It did not apply to payroll tax evasion involving under-the-counter payments which had not been disclosed at the time, which Revenue had not become aware of in the course of its ordinary operations and which were unearthed directly as a result of the evidence supplied to the tribunal, and the subsequent comprehensive investigation undertaken by the Revenue.

Speaker.P: They will benefit from the amnesty now, of course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: I will come to that later. Following receipt of information from the tribunal in August, 1991, which indicated that untaxed payments had been made to employees under the guise of bogus haulier payments, the Revenue launched a major investigation. After initial discoveries by Revenue officers, the Goodman group of companies admitted to making untaxed payments to employees, and facilitated the quantification of the tax undercharges. Revenue inquiries, which included an examination of the extensive records of the group at all its locations, continued during 1992 and 1993. Some of the Revenue officers were requested to give written statements and verbal evidence to the tribunal during the period. This evidence formed part of the basis for the tribunal finding that widespread payroll tax evasion took place.

As stated in the tribunal's report efforts continued in 1993, after the end of the tribunal's public sittings, and in early 1994, to reach a final position on the payroll tax undercharges. The discussions took place against the background of the tax amnesty scheme. The tribunal report records that in January, 1994 the group offered £4.1 million to settle its outstanding payroll tax liabilities.

In its public statement issued on 4 August 1994, after publication of the tribunal's report, the Revenue Commissioners stated that more than half of this sum of £4.1 million was paid by the amnesty deadline of 14 January 1994. This payment covers the liability of certain companies in the group and, subject to compliance with other conditions, these companies only could qualify for the general amnesty on interest and penalties. The remainder of the £4.1 million referred to relates to the liabilities of other companies in the group. The companies to which these liabilities refer do not qualify for the exemption from interest and penalties under the amnesty legislation.

The Revenue Commissioners stated that the overall offer, including the question of interest and penalties, is still under discussion with the group. The position is complex due to the number of years involved up to 5 April 1991 and the large number of individual companies which have liabilities in this matter, some of which are no longer trading.

MainHeading.P: The pursuit of this case is a matter for the Revenue Commissioners. I do not propose to comment further on it. However, I would like to refer to comments which have been made about the question of the application of the amnesty in a case of this type.

The precise scope of the amnesty scheme was made quite clear in the Official Report on the Waiver of Certain Tax, Interest and Penalties Act, 1993. Under the first part of the scheme — the incentive amnesty — individual taxpayers could settle their tax affairs by paying 15 per cent of the relevant income or gains. In view of the advantages conferred, that part of the scheme was very tightly drawn and companies were specifically excluded.

The second part of the scheme, the general amnesty was, as the title indicates, more generally available, as had been the previous amnesty in 1988. Under this part, all the underlying tax had to be paid but interest and penalties were waived. Companies were not excluded from the general amnesty. The whole idea was to give people a last chance to put their affairs in order — for those who were evading taxes outside the system to come within it, and for those already in the system but who had not paid their taxes to do so.

It has been suggested that the amnesty scheme should not have been applied to tax evaders. In the course of the amnesty debate in this House, I pointed out that the scheme covered the generality of undischarged pre-April 1991 liabilities and was focused in particular on liabilities not on the record because of concealment. Evaders are the people at whom the amnesty was primarily aimed, so as to help clean up the situation for the future.

Under the legislation it is a matter for the Revenue Commissioners to decide whether the conditions laid down for availing of the general amnesty have been met in particular cases. Of course, it must do this in an even-handed way. It cannot exclude any individual or company which satisfies the conditions laid down by the Oireachtas. Deputy Bruton referred yesterday to the 1993 Amnesty and claimed that evaded taxes that were the subject of court proceedings were excluded, but not evaded taxes that were before a tribunal. In fact, the only amnesty which applied to companies was the general amnesty. This covered interest and penalties not the tax itself. The only court cases excluded were those in respect of which interest or penalties had actually been imposed by a court. This was exactly the same position as in the corresponding 1988 amnesty. The Deputy may have had in mind the 15 per cent incentive amnesty which excluded any sum of tax the recovery of which was the subject of court proceedings. That amnesty applied to individuals only and not to companies.

While on this subject, it should not be lost sight of that the two amnesties, provided for in the 1993 Act, brought in close to £260 million. These moneys were used to reduce the liabilities of the State in several areas. A large portion, £100 million, went to help put the health service, both hospitals and health boards, on a sounder financial footing by allowing them to reduce their dependence on excessive debt levels and ensure prompt payment by these agencies to their suppliers, small businesses in many cases. Without the amnesty it would have been more difficult to solve the problem.

In the course of Revenue investigations during the tribunal more limited instances of avoidance/evasion were uncovered in other meat industry companies. These investigations have either resulted in settlements with the Revenue or are under inquiry.

The extent of tax evasion in the Goodman companies in particular which has emerged from the tribunal is of considerable concern. The report of the tribunal found that the allegations made about the making of under the counter payments to employees had been fully substantiated. It further found that the making of such payments was concealed in the records of the companies in the group, by the recording of fictitious payments to hauliers and farmers, which deceived the Revenue Authorities at the time and that the whole evasion scheme was “very professionally put together”.

The Revenue Commissioners have greatly strengthened their anti-evasion operations in recent years. Streamlining tax offices' operations after the introduction of self-assessment in 1988, meant that resources began to be released to confront non-compliance. An audit programme was put in place in 1989 and 1990 for income tax audits, with audit units being established throughout the country. This was extended to companies in early 1991. Audit activity has been refined and expanded since then. Audit units were reorganised in 1993 on a broad, sectoral basis and all audits operate as an integrated part of an overall audit programme in each tax district. An anti-avoidance unit was formally established in the office in 1991 to investigate schemes purporting to be tax avoidance schemes. This unit has been especially effective in countering artificial schemes. There are now over 600 members of staff engaged on audit, investigative and specific compliance work, compared with about 200 in 1990. Following the Single Market changes in 1993, Customs and Excise officials are also making an important contribution to tax compliance work.

Partly in response to the emerging evidence of abuse in certain sectors, the Government has taken action to increase substantially the legislative powers available to the Revenue Commissioners. Deputies will recall that in the 1992 Finance Act changes were made to rationalise and harmonise the legislative basis of outdoor inquiries by providing for broadly similar powers of entry, inspection and removal of records for each tax, particularly in respect of PAYE compliance. Inspectors are now able to focus on all the taxable operations of a taxpayer and on the interaction of those operations. An obligation was also imposed on meat processors to deduct tax at source, in respect of sums to be paid to subcontractors, in respect of meat processing operations.
Further powers were given to Revenue in the amnesty legislation and penalties for evasion were increased for the post-amnesty period.
Revenue officials have been trained in the use of the new powers aimed at non-compliant businesses. Every effort is being made to avoid burdens on bona fide taxpayers.
